title: User Interface Software and Technology

images.cover: |cover.jpg|An illustration of 1's and 0's with a stick figure sitting on one, reading.|User interfaces are where people and technology meet.|[Amy J. Ko|https://faculty.washington.edu/ajko/]|
images.unknown: |error.gif|An animated gif of television noise.|Uh oh, something went wrong.|Blackworker (GIFER)|

description:
The HCI community has a long history of innovation in user interface software and technologies, but there are few surveys or review of all of this research. This book attempts to summarize much of this knowledge, providing a living online textbook for UX designers, researchers, design-literate developers to learn from and leverage this ever-expanding body of knowledge.

I hope you enjoy! If not, please file an [issue|https://github.com/amyjko/user-interface-software-and-technology/issues/new] on the [the book's GitHub repository|https://github.com/amyjko/user-interface-software-and-technology/].

chapters.title: A History of Interfaces
chapters.image: |mouse.jpg|A photograph of the original computer mouse.|User interfaces have always evolved.|Michael Hicks|

chapters.title: A Theory of Interfaces
chapters.image: |theory.jpg|A very close subpixel image of a mouse cursor.|What is an interface?|[Umberto|https://unsplash.com/photos/deb2EnbWPr8]|

chapters.title: What Interfaces Mediate
chapters.image: |mediation.jpg|A top down photograph of three people using one laptop, all with arms reached out to point.|Interfaces are between us and computation, information, and other people.|[John Schnobrich|https://unsplash.com/photos/2FPjlAyMQTA]|

chapters.title: Programming Interfaces
chapters.image: |programming.jpg|A close up shot of a code editor showing some Python code.|Programming languages are the most powerful and least usable of computer interfaces.|[Chris Ried|https://unsplash.com/photos/ieic5Tq8YMk]|

chapters.title: Interactive Interfaces
chapters.image: |xerox-star.jpg|A screenshot of the Xerox star user interface and it's word processing application and desktop|Graphical user interfaces did not have to be this way.|Xerox|

chapters.title: Interface Architecture
chapters.image: |angola.jpg|A modern architecture of an apartment building, figuratively resembling software architecture.|Architecture is how interface implementations are organized.|Costa Lopes|

chapters.title: Accessibility
chapters.image: |braille.jpg|A braille numeric keypad|Some access technologies are a bandage for inaccessible designs|CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons|

chapters.title: Pointing
chapters.image: |wearable.jpg|A photograph of a person touching an Apple Watch screen|A wearable device with particularly small targets|fancycrave1, Pixabay|

chapters.title: Text Entry
chapters.image: |keyboard.jpg|A photograph of a kitten sitting on a computer keyboard.|A standard text entry device and it's avid user.|Flickr/dougewoods|

chapters.title: Hand-Based Input
chapters.image: |human-hands.jpg|Two human hands in the sun facing a blue sky|Hands are versatile tools for input.|Luisfi CC BY-SA 3.0 via Wikimedia Commons|

chapters.title: Body-Based Input
chapters.image: |kinect.jpg|A man and a woman playing XBox Kinect game.|A man and a woman playing XBox Kinect game with their bodies.|Sergey Galyonkin, Flickr|

chapters.title: 2D Visual Output
chapters.image: |pong.png|A screenshot of the original Pong video game with two paddles, a ball, and scores.|Pong, one of the earliest arcade video games was also one of the first software applications to use graphics|Unknown|

chapters.title: 3D Visual Output
chapters.image: |hololens.jpg|A screenshot of Microsoft's Hololens Minecraft experience|Microsoft's HoloLens|Microsoft|

chapters.title: Physical Output
chapters.image: |makerbot.jpg|A Makerbot 3D printer printing a nested dodecahedron.|Some computer output is tangible.|CC0 Public Domain|

chapters.title: Help
chapters.image: |frustration.png|A stick figure man looking frustrated at a computer screen.|Things fall apart.|CC0 Creative Commons|

chapters.title: Intellectual Property
chapters.image: |applevmicrosoft.jpg|Legal paperwork with Apple and Microsoft logos|A few small cases have shaped U.S. case law on interfaces.|ACM|

chapters.title: Translation
chapters.image: |comotion.jpg|The front desk of the University of Washington's CoMotion, which supports technology transfer from research.|Gaps between research and practice are numerous, but many things can help.|University of Washington|

chapters.title: Interface Ethics
chapters.image: |ring.jpg|A photograph of a Ring Doorbell mounted on a brick wall.|Interfaces are not neutral.|Ring|

abilitybaseddesign.definition: Interface designs that adapt to the abilities of their users.

absolutepointing.definition: Pointing devices in which the physical coordinates of input are mapped directly onto the interface coordinate system (e.g., touchscreens).

accesstech.definition: Interfaces that are used in tadem with other intefaces to improve their poor accessibility.

accessibility.definition: A quality of user interfaces that determines what abilities are required to use an interface. Accessible interfaces include people regardless of ability; inaccessible interfaces exclude people with particular abilities.

affordance.definition: The potential for action in an interface, ultimately defined by what underlying functionalty it has been designed and engineered to support.

api.definition: A collection of code used for computing particular things, designed for reuse by others without having to understand the details of the computation. For example, an API might mediate access to facial recognition algorithms, date arithmetic, or trigonometric functions.

ar.definition: An interface that layers on interactive virtual content into the physical world.

breakdown.definition: Mistakes and confusion that occur because a user's mental model is inconsistent with an interface's actual functionality.

ccc.definition: Any form of communication that is conducted through some computational device, such as a phone, tablet, laptop, desktop, smart speaker, etc.

continuoustextentry.definition: Providing some ambiguous source of text (e.g., speech, gesture) and having an interface translate it into text.

compositing.definition: Layering visual imagery and filters, from top to bottom, to construct scenes from individual layers of graphics.

constraint.definition: A technique of software development in which the value of one thing is made to always be equal to some transofrmation of another value (e.g., the left edge of this square should always be aligned horizontally with the right edge of this circle.)

convention.definition: A widely-used and widely-learned interface design pattern (e.g., a web form, a login screen, a hamburger menu on a mobile website).

directpointing.definition: Pointing devices in which the input for pointing and the corresponding feedback in response occur in the same physical place (e.g., a touchscreen).

discretetextentry.definition: Explicitly and unambiguously selecting characters, words, and phrases for entry (e.g., with a keyboard).

event.definition: A user input such as a mouse click, tap, drag, or verbal utterance that may trigger a state change in a user interface's state.

eup.definition: Any programming done as a means to accomplish some other goal (in contrast to software engineering, which is done for the sole purpose of creating software for others to use).

feedback.definition: Output from a computer program intended to explain what action a computer took in response to a user's input (e.g., confirmation messages, error messages, or visible updates).

function.definition: An idea from mathematics of using algorithms to map some input (e.g., numbers, text, or other data), to some output. Functions can be as simple as basic arithmetic (e.g., _multiply_, which takes two numbers and computes their product), or as complex as machine vision (_object recognition_, which takes an image and a machine learned classifier trained on millions of images and produces a set of text descriptions of objects in the image.

graphics.definition: The use of computer hardware to create static, dynamic, and interactive two and three dimensional imagery.

gulfofex.definition: Everything a person must learn in order to acheive their goal with an interface, including learning what the interface is and is not capable of and how to operate it correctly.

gulfofeval.definition: Everything a person must learn in order to understand the effect of their action on an interface, including understanding error messages or a lack of response from an interface.

immersion.definition: The illusory experience of interacting with virtual content for what represents, as opposed to the low-level light, sound, haptics and other sensory information from whic it is composed.

indirectpointing.definition: Pointing devices in which the input for pointing and the corresponding feedback in response occur in different physical places (e.g., a mouse and a screen).

infoarch.definition: The study and practice of organizing information and inferfaces to support searching, browsing, and sensemaking.

mentalmodel.definition: A person's beliefs about an interface's affordances and how to operate them.

metadata.definition: Data about data; for example, metadata about a digital photograph might include where it was taken, who took it, and a description of what is in the image.

mvc.definition: A way of organizing a user interface implementation to separate how data is stored (the model), how data is presented (the view), and how data is changed in response to user input (the controller).

predictivetextentry.definition: Providing input that suggests the desired text and having the interface predict what input might be intended.

presence.definition: The sense of being physically located in a place and space.

relativepointing.definition: Pointing devices in which changes in the physical coordinates of input device are mapped directly _changes_ to the current position in an interface coordinate system (e.g., mice).

signifier.definition: Any indicator of an affordance in an interface.

state.definition: A particular mode or configuration of a user interface that can be changed through user input. For example, a button might be hovered over or not, or user on a web page might be logged in or not.

ui.definition: A special kind of software designed to map human activities in the physical world (clicks, presses, taps, speech, etc.) to functions defined in a computer program.

universal.definition: Interfaces that are accessible to any person, regardless of their abilities.

vr.definition: Interfaces that attempt to achieve immersion and presence through audio, vidoe, and tactile illusion.
